title: Hint
text:
1) Rewrite each term in the equation $$64$$ × $$4^{3x}$$ $$=$$ $$16$$ using powers of $$2$$.
• $$64$$ $$=$$ $$2^6$$.
• $$16$$ $$=$$ $$2^4$$.
• $$4$$ $$=$$ $$2^2$$.

2) Replace these into the given equation:
$$2^6$$ × $$\left(2^2ight)^{3x}$$ $$=$$ $$2^4$$.

3) Simplify the exponential expression $$\left(2^2ight)^{3x}$$:
$$\left(2^2ight)^{3x}$$ $$=$$ 2**(2 × 3x) $$=$$ $$2^{6x}$$.

4) Now the equation is:
$$2^6$$ × $$2^{6x}$$ $$=$$ $$2^4$$.

5) Combine like bases on the left side by adding exponents:
2**(6 + 6x) $$=$$ $$2^4$$.

6) Since the bases are equal, set the exponents equal to each other:
$$6$$ + $$6x$$ $$=$$ $$4$$.

7) Solve for x:
$$6x$$ $$=$$ $$4$$ - $$6$$
$$6x$$ $$=$$ $$-2$$
...
